subject: Re: [junit] Re: Using System.out.println("something") ???
msgSnippet: ... So let them log.  After some time, maybe they ll see that it has no benefit and they ll stop doing it.  Or maybe there is a real benefit (I don t see any
messageBody:
> Some of my coworkers want to log.

So let them log. After some time, maybe they'll see that it has no benefit and
they'll stop doing it. Or maybe there is a real benefit (I don't see any but I
can be wrong).

> I also object using System.out.println("...") in JUnit tests. Some
> coworkers do this. Maybe they understand the nature of JUnit tests
> one time.

wait until you have 1000 tests... the more tests, the more outputs and it will
be harder and harder to separate the good (infos why a test failed) and the bad
(noise about passing tests).

But it would be interesting to know _what_ they are printing out.

Sometimes it's handy to know the testcase that is currently running (typically
if you have suddently an infinite loop...):
- the bad solution is to add a println() at the beginning of the test
- the good solution is to write a listener that outputs the name of the
currently running test. You can then register/deregister the listener if you
need it or not.

-Vladimir

--
Vladimir R. Bossicard
